titleInfo.title: Geological map of Sevier County, Tenn. (1841)

mods.abstract: Drawn by Gerard Troost, Tennessee's first State Geologist, this geological map of Sevier County shows the early road system, rivers, a topographical rendering of the Great Smoky Mountains, and mineral resources including slate and limestone. Other landmarks include the Holston River, the towns of Dandridge and Sevierville, Yellow Springs, Wiers Cove and Dawson's Cove. His main concern is to illustrate occurrences of potential commercial products such as "roofing slate," white oak, alum and limestone.

This map was printed in the Sixth Report (to the Tennessee General Assembly) of Dr. Gerard Troost, State Geologist. Troost, a native of the Netherlands, was Tennessee's first state geologist and first president of the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. He served as professor of chemistry, geology, and mineralogy at the University of Nashville for 22 years. For more information on Troost, consult the article in the Peabody Journal of Education 30, no. 5 (March 1953) by Ellen V. Piers, called ""Gerard Troost, Pioneer Scientist"" pages 265-274.
